messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Pin holes ?????
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Could be, I can t see enough in the photo to tell.  I would have thought an Edo period piece from the look of it, but if there are tekkotsu it could be
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
Could be, I can't see enough in the photo to tell. I would have thought an Edo period piece from the look of it, but if there are tekkotsu it could be earlier. The curved bamboo at the top is a nice design variation.

Jim

Jim und all,

how about this similar ( NOT AXE ) example ? It has iron bones on the
surface ( 6 o'clock at edge of the treasure weight, also linear bones
on the mimi.

Owari ? ko-Shoami ?


www.image-hosting.net/images/messageboard/retalt/UntitledMA10663548-
0001.jpg


milt


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Pin holes ?????
messages.msgSnippet: Hi. Those sorts of holes are sometimes seen on tsuba that have been recycled at least once in the West. It was once distressingly common to wire, sometimes
messages.messageBody:
Hi.
Those sorts of holes are sometimes seen on tsuba that have been
recycled at least once in the West. It was once distressingly common to
wire, sometimes solder, tsuba to some sort of frame or mesh for
"decorative" purposes.
Arnold

>>> ikkanshi@... 07/27/05 8:22 PM >>>
All, in this tsuba ( Owari or Kyo Shoami maybe ?? ) in the punch marks
on the face, are 3 distinct pin holes or drill holes. Are these to
enable the metal to be broken away easier when punching out the iron ?.
Seems reasonable.

http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata43/egk251-02.jpg

http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata43/egk251-05.jpg

http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata43/egk251-04.jpg

Any thoughts welcome.

Cheers

rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Pin holes ?????
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, Being a pretty late one it s hard to say, but it s more Shoami than Owari.  I don t know what the motif means, but some time spent with the usual books
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Being a pretty late one it's hard to say, but it's more Shoami than Owari. I don't know what the motif means, but some time spent with the usual books might turn something up.

Jim
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, July 27, 2005 6:58 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Pin holes ?????


thanks Jim, so weight's and split bamboo ??, any particular theme there ?.

Also, Is Owari close for a kantei ?, I have seen similar examples in
some of my books, though of course theme's were borrowed heavily. I
thought Kyo Shoami was another possibility.

Many thanks as usual.

Rich

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Pin holes ?????
messages.msgSnippet: Strange Rich.  Normally that sort of  punching was done to spread the metal out laterally (to shrink the nakago-ana), so nothing would be broken away or gouged
messages.messageBody:
Strange Rich. Normally that sort of punching was done to spread the metal out laterally (to shrink the nakago-ana), so nothing would be broken away or gouged out. This case is pretty extreme and to no obvious effect, but still, removing iron isn't difficult and the holes wouldn't be much help as far as I can imagine. Iron is soft and it looks like the holes were drilled after the punching. It strikes me as some later fiddling to mount it on something, but who knows.

The design is weights, not axe heads, btw (not your idea, I know). The Japanese tool for splitting bamboo looks like a broken off sword (no kisaki). A friend of mine from Higashi Hiroshima comes from a farming family and their bamboo knife is in fact a broken Masahide sword with a nice mei.

Jim



All, in this tsuba ( Owari or Kyo Shoami maybe ?? ) in the punch marks
on the face, are 3 distinct pin holes or drill holes. Are these to
enable the metal to be broken away easier when punching out the iron ?.
Seems reasonable.

http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata43/egk251-02.jpg

http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata43/egk251-05.jpg

http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata43/egk251-04.jpg

Any thoughts welcome.

Cheers

rich



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Pin holes ?????
messages.msgSnippet: The weight (fundo) was one of the Myriad Treasures (takaramono) associated with the Seven Gods of Good Luck, who carry them in a sack. As such it is an
messages.messageBody:
The weight (fundo) was one of the Myriad Treasures (takaramono) associated with the Seven Gods of Good Luck, who carry them in a sack. As such it is an auspicious symbol. Perhaps the bamboo is split open to demonstrate that it is empty (in the positive Taoist/Buddhist sense) at its core, as a samurai opens his belly to disclose his sincerity.

David Zincavage

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Menuki Thoughts?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi - One of my favorite articles on menuki was presented in Token Taikai, a booklet containing transcripts of eleven papers presented during the 1976 Token
messages.messageBody:
Hi -

One of my favorite articles on menuki was presented in Token Taikai, a booklet containing transcripts of eleven papers presented during the 1976 Token Taikai sponsored by the NCJSC. The late Tom Buttweiler's artice, "The History of Pre-Edo Menuki" was nicely illustrated and clearly showed the various styles of menuki that evolved during that time-frame in history. That article was a key stimulus that set me off on my fascination with early menuki. This publication would really be a worthwhile one for the NCJSC to consider reprinting one day. If not that, then perhaps the JSS/US could get permission to reprint several of these papers in their newsletter.

Another 2-volume set of books out of Germany several years ago (1995) -- one volume on tsuba, the other on kodogu -- had a pretty good section on menuki. I'm not sure of the formal title to the "set" but it was by H. U. B. Verlag (ISBM 3-931150-00-3). Nice large photographs with the text translated into English, German and Japanese.

In all these years I have seen only one small illustrated article that dealt with the making of menuki. That appeared in a NBTHK Token Bijutsu journal perhaps 15 years ago and showed a modern day menuki maker creating his works. Years later I tried to locate that article to get it translated, but I never did locate it again. Not much written (in depth) about menuki, so it seems.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: David Zincavage
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 25, 2005 1:44 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Menuki Thoughts?


Bob McCoy provides the following in an undated NCJSC fact sheet distributed with an unknown issue of To-Ron.






References:

1. "Menuki, The magnificent Miniatures" By R.B. Caldwell, Arts of Asia, Jan/Feb 1992, pp70-77

2. "Menuki, The Magnificent Miniatures of Japan" by R.B. Caldwell, JSS/US, Jul/Aug 1990, vol 22, #4, ppl 7-31

3. "Shumi no menuki" by Kanzan Sato, ed. Limited printing of 800 copies, 1969, boxed, 306 pages.

4. "Kinko Mino Bori" by Kokubo Kenichi. Published by Token Shunjo Shinbunsha, Tokyo, 1973.

5. "Swords of Japan, A visual Glossary" by Kotoken Kajihara, 500+ pages, hardbound.

6. "Fine Japanese Sword Fittings, MENUKI", by Musashiya Co, LTD, Vol 1, 162pp FIB, 1985,

7. "Fine Japanese Sword Fittings, MENUKT', by Musashiya Co, LTD, Vol 2, 146pp FIB, 1994,

8. "Nihon to Koza, Kodogu Part 1, Volume VI", 1993, 481pp HB, translated by Harry AFU Watson



There was also another color four page fold-out, dated 2002/1, distributed with an issue of To-Ron a bit later.


----- Original Message -----
From: sigp210
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 25, 2005 10:35 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Menuki Thoughts?


Mr Gilbert,
Many thanks for the reply. I had given up on the thread attracting any
reply. Is there any way to estimate a period on menuki like this, or
are they usually just lumped into the "late edo" period?
I haven't seen a lot of info on menuki anywhere. Are there any
(English) books with a decent chapter on menuki at all, and what are
the things to look out for in early menuki?

Regards,
Brian

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...> wrote:
> Brian,
> They're not Goto, although they are following the style. I don't
think that it is possible to attribute them to a specific group. At
shinsa work like this is often described as Kyo-Kanagushi (Kyoto metal
fittings maker).
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> Hi all,
> I recently made an offer on a set of menuki on eBay, and got them. I'm
> not a fittings guy at all, but wanted a nice pair for a future
> mounting project, and as an example for study.
> They were described as Goto or at least waki-goto. I doubt they are
> Goto...but am wondering if anyone has any thoughts on the quality,
> school etc? Are there any identifying marks on menuki that might lead
> towards a certain school?
> Was really attracted to them because of the fine carving work, and
> detail. The colour is a nice dark brownish-black shakudo, not like the
> lighting in the photo shows.
> They are actually nicer than in the pics..with some very fine carving,
> and detail on the toes, ribs, tail etc. Some odd marks on the
> legs..which are 2 ovals with a small dot in the middle.
> Middle to late edo I assume? Condition is very good. Any comments from
> "menuki guys" appreciated.
>
> Pic is at
> http://www.image-hosting.net/images/messageboard/retalt/Menuki.jpg
>
> Thanks,
> Brian
>
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Menuki Thoughts?
messages.msgSnippet: Brian, They re not Goto, although they are following the style.  I don t think that it is possible to attribute them to a specific group.  At shinsa work like
messages.messageBody:
Brian,
They're not Goto, although they are following the style. I don't think that it is possible to attribute them to a specific group. At shinsa work like this is often described as Kyo-Kanagushi (Kyoto metal fittings maker).

Jim



Hi all,
I recently made an offer on a set of menuki on eBay, and got them. I'm
not a fittings guy at all, but wanted a nice pair for a future
mounting project, and as an example for study.
They were described as Goto or at least waki-goto. I doubt they are
Goto...but am wondering if anyone has any thoughts on the quality,
school etc? Are there any identifying marks on menuki that might lead
towards a certain school?
Was really attracted to them because of the fine carving work, and
detail. The colour is a nice dark brownish-black shakudo, not like the
lighting in the photo shows.
They are actually nicer than in the pics..with some very fine carving,
and detail on the toes, ribs, tail etc. Some odd marks on the
legs..which are 2 ovals with a small dot in the middle.
Middle to late edo I assume? Condition is very good. Any comments from
"menuki guys" appreciated.

Pic is at
http://www.image-hosting.net/images/messageboard/retalt/Menuki.jpg

Thanks,
Brian



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Menuki Thoughts?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I recently made an offer on a set of menuki on eBay, and got them. I m not a fittings guy at all, but wanted a nice pair for a future mounting project,
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,
I recently made an offer on a set of menuki on eBay, and got them. I'm
not a fittings guy at all, but wanted a nice pair for a future
mounting project, and as an example for study.
They were described as Goto or at least waki-goto. I doubt they are
Goto...but am wondering if anyone has any thoughts on the quality,
school etc? Are there any identifying marks on menuki that might lead
towards a certain school?
Was really attracted to them because of the fine carving work, and
detail. The colour is a nice dark brownish-black shakudo, not like the
lighting in the photo shows.
They are actually nicer than in the pics..with some very fine carving,
and detail on the toes, ribs, tail etc. Some odd marks on the
legs..which are 2 ovals with a small dot in the middle.
Middle to late edo I assume? Condition is very good. Any comments from
"menuki guys" appreciated.

Pic is at
http://www.image-hosting.net/images/messageboard/retalt/Menuki.jpg

Thanks,
Brian
